Pit_Observation.activities: Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This avalanche was originally reported on 11/25/2023. The UAC forecaster team went in to look at it on November 29, 2023. First impression was that this was a D2 (large enough to bury a person) avalanche that ran on dry facets above a crust approximately 1' off the ground. Total depth of snow adjacent to this avalanche at 10,340' was 42" (107cm) and the test results showed ECTX x 2. However, a propagation saw test PST in the dry facets above the dirt crust showed propagation to the end.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Fresh wolf tracks at 8300' (relatively supportable snowpack- considering all of the facets).
Generally weak and unsupportable snowpack above 8500' in this area. Firm rain crusts with minimal snowpack below 8000'.

User.range: Banff, Yoho and Kootenay National Parks
User.name: Satu Kouri

Location.range: Banff, Yoho and Kootenay National Parks
Location.name: Bow Summit N

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Ski tracks on slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: About 400' higher, exactly the same stratigraphy and localized collapsing. There were a lot of tracks, so I think many collapses had been triggered. The Lane's Leap slide path had cracks from a previous collapse as well as ski tracks. The combination of ski tracks in the slide path, plus collapsing, and cracking indicates that the snowpack is weak, but lacking something for it to produce an avalanche.

In study plot. Basal MFcr not noted in plot - noticed pockets of it occasionally while setting up big chair, but very spotty / seems mostly to have faceted away from what I've seen.
Unable to complete effective CT, did some quick hand shears with no planar breaks.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, widespread; Cracking; Recent avalanche activity on different slopes; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Maa kivirakkaa. Lumipyry ja tuuli kuljetti lunta rinteelle. WS paksuus ja kovuus vaihteli suuresti noin 20-50cm vlill. Kuopan kohdalla WS pehmemp ja sit oli vhemmn (testitulokset eivt juuri korreloineet tilanteen kanssa). Samalla rinteell paljon laajoja humahduksia ja halkemia lpi koko etelseinn SH kerroksesta. Pienest jyrkemmst muodosta mys WS oli lhtenyt liikkeelle ja liukunut noin 5m. Kaakonkulma hetke myhemmin vyryi kaukolaukaisuna (koko 2).
Snowpit dug midslope, below where most previous NE wind scouring had occurred.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Previously wind loaded slope to intentionally find a cohesive slab to test propagation. Experienced a decent collapse when skinning away

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Maa kivirakkaa. Yleiskatsaus itpuolen rinteille. Lumensyvyys noin 400moh vaihteli 40-80cm vlill. Lumi oli peittnyt eptasaisuudet ja kivet mys alempana metsnrajassa.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: 32 cm snow pack consisting of several MF crusts and faceted snow was doubled last night during strong sustained easterly winds. This pencil+ density slab sits on top of weaker larger facets and MF forms/ crusts.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: pit dug on crown of recent avalanche triggered by AE in ski area. Strong sustained easterly winds transported snow on top of a melt freeze crust that created a P+ slab 36cm's deep

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Alpine bowl below ridgetop, glacier ice, variable HS across slope, ranging 80-120. Mod results down 12 in near surface facets. Hard results down 35 on IFrc. JW/MO.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area;

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Annual Thanksgiving Day Pit in the same location as previous years. Far skier's left side above KB Ridge. Floating average since 1986 is just under 83cm for this area. Snowfall and winds were increasing through the morning and the surface snow was starting to slab a bit. No Whumpfs or shooting cracks observed. General HS at 9K was 20-30cm with 50-55cm on the north aspects.

Pit_Observation.activities: Cracking;
Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Pit dug in a Ski Area;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: While the MFcr is our main layer of concern due to its destructive potential and widespread distribution, it's sensitivity is stubborn. The wind slab that makes up the top 10cm of the snowpack is confined to specific terrain, however it is touchy, and is also being identified as a layer to monitor, specifically in larger terrain features where entrainment is possible. -NAK Avy Team

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Snow at 9400', North facing was 30cm with 2 breakable crusts and a basal ice layer that was starting to facet. Poor structure where there was snow above 9400' shady aspects. Stability was only fair because there was no real slab to speak of.
